text: Umerin, a plum fairy, promotes the town of Ogose in Saitama, Japan.
Not an owl, apparently
Nanamaru, “a mysterious creature shaped like an owl”, is the mascot for Tokyo’s Toshima Ward.
Hyakuman-san, a floral-patterned traditional doll with a mustache, is the mascot of Japan’s Ishikawa Prefecture.
Kapal, the big kappa (water imp) mascot for Shiki City, in Tobu Ikebukuro Department Store today
Emuemu-san, an expressionless egg-shaped seagull, is the mascot of the Minatomirai train line in Yokohama, Japan.
Here are three versions of Keyakki the tree, tourism mascot of Miyagi, Japan.
That’s a crazy story!
Melon Kuma, a terrifying hybrid of a melon and a bear, is the mascot of Yubari City (where melons are grown and bears roam).
I like that beer!
Arukuma, the mascot of Nagano Prefecture, is a green bear who loves walking and wears an apple hat.
OMC-kun, a sophisticated art-loving raccoon dog, is a mascot from the Southern Alps of Yamanashi, Japan.
I’ve seen him at the same location! That’s Chosei Tonyu-kun, a carton of soy milk.
Sure, probably!
Daikonchama, a friendly radish, is an unofficial mascot for Ota Ward in Tokyo.
Matsudo-san, the bouncy businessman mascot of Matsudo City, was at Tokyo Dome City yesterday. The kanji for Matsudo (松戸) is on his face.
Tomichan, a watermelon-headed runner, is the mascot for Tomisato City, where competitors in an annual marathon munch on melon slices as they run.
Two Chiitans today at Tokyo Dome City
Rippy, a short-eared rabbit who’s often mistaken for a hamster, at Tokyo Dome yesterday
Pokapyon, a yellow and purple alien, is the mascot of Sunpot, an environmentally friendly heating equipment manufacturer.
Kamarin, the mascot of Kamaishi City, has flames from a blast furnace in one hand, a local flower in the other, and a fish on his head.
Geoffrey the Giraffe, the Toys Я Us mascot, at a mascot event in Japan.
Fujimocchi, a round yellow pigeon, is the mascot for Fujinaga, a company who help prevent property damage by birds.
No, he’s just a YouTuber, and he sells lots of merch.
Peanuts-kun is an underpants-wearing virtual YouTuber.
Po, a fairy with an apple balanced on his head, is the mascot of lida Puppet Festival.
Mikoto-chan, a mascot from the town of Shinkamigoto, in the Goto Islands, is dressed like a lion dancer from a local festival.
Sometimes! I don’t know much more about this one, though.
Ami-go, a cat with a flying fish on its head, is the mascot of Shin-Kamigotō town, Japan.
Ikana Cat is the mascot for Taiyo Life Insurance.
Saigo Tsun, the dog mascot of Satsumasendai City, takes it easy.
Kusurin, whose head is a medicine box, promotes medicine from Toyama Prefecture.
I think he’s back later today.
The giant, sleepy Pokémon Snorlax appeared in Pokémon Center Mega Tokyo today.
Non-chan, a baby salmon, is the mascot of Noda, a village in Iwate, Japan.
Good info!
Fukuro-kun the owl is the mascot Hanamaki Onsen hot springs resort.
Kizuru, a giant paper crane, is the mascot of Grulla Morioka FC.
Local mascots Go-chan (based on local historical figure Oeyo) and Shiromochi-kun (a rice cake with a historical helmet) at the Tsu City Sweets Festival.
Nice!
Wolfy, a wolf in sheep’s clothing, is the mascot of Japan’s Nagoya Broadcasting Network. (This is a big inflatable version I spotted in Nagoya.)
Ise Wanko, a dog who wanders the land looking for sweet snacks, at the Tsu City Sweets Festival today
NHK Broadcasting mascot Domo-kun, in the Nagoya NHK Building
He loves it too much to share!
I ran into Mochimaru, a quokka character who loves mochi.
Probably! It’s only called that in Japan. It originated in China, but seems to be more popular here.
Budding Pop (also known as Nagakusa-kun), is a popular character from China.
Hyotan, whose head is a gourd, is a character from Tokyo.
Mamehiro is a dancing squirrel character from Shibuya, Tokyo.
The kanji for Mie can also be read “Mijuu,” which is why he got the gig.
Ah, because of the ninja connection
Today I met Oshawott, a sea otter-like Pokémon who also promotes tourism to Japan’s Mie Prefecture.
Iruma Cable TV mascot Chatsumin is a green tea-loving bird.
Bed Hair Penta (a penguin with bed hair) is a character from the Japanese picture book series, Penguin Airplane Factory.
Here's Mamor-kun, a little firefighter from the anime Fire Force, in Shibuya.
Nagomi Shibakko is a black Shiba Inu from Arashiyama in Kyoto.
Cherry blossom monkeys Yockey and his grandfather Yockey-G are mascots for Yoga, Tokyo.
Rose, a unicorn from the planet Cotton Candy (one of several "Unicorn No Cony" toy characters), on the street in Yokosuka City:
Hauto-kun, a moody blue bird with a propellor on his head, comes from a dance studio in Ichikawa City, Japan, named How to Fly.
Today I saw Exeggutor, a three-headed Pokémon, in Tokyo, working a tourism mascot for Japan’s Miyazaki Prefecture, because it looks like the palm trees that grow there.
Sikissy is a portrait-painting portrait painting from Fukuoka City.
Manekki, a lucky waving cat mascot, is the mascot for Manekineko Karaoke.
Puimo, a guinea pig dressed as a lion, is the mascot for the Japanese game site, Tsunagari.
Marupu is a dog from Utsunomiya City whose hobby is celebrating things.

In Togoshi Ginza, Tokyo, local cat mascot
Togoshi Ginjiro (aka Gin-chan, right) hangs out with Osaki Ichibantaro, a green, bear-like alien from nearby Osaki.
Wow!
Mr. Ballhead is a surreal performance artist.
Tohoku Electric Power's mascot is Makapu, a blue bird from an island called Makapu Island, who enjoys fishing.
Popular toy and anime character, Pickles the Frog, on Tokyo Character Street today
Najavu, a cheerful, well-dressed calico cat, is the main mascot for Namjatown indoor theme park in Tokyo.
Spanky is an unemployed alien dog guitarist from Shinagawa, Tokyo.
Not much. I should look into that!
Asapi the friendly flower is the mascot Owariasahi City.
Apparently so, I’m just finding out now. And hog bile!
Good grief!
Bottle Man Joe is a sentient bottle of Kyushin Tablets, which ease breathlessness and heart palpitations.
Jamu Lyon, a jam fairy, is the mascot for Kitchen Benton's Miracle Jam.
Ohta Inyan, a blue and white cat, is the mascot for Ohta Issan gastrointestinal medicine.
The Noppon Brothers are a pair of pink siblings in overalls, who are the mascots for Tokyo Tower.
Yeah, in a very basic way. One has A for Akasaka on his head, another has ア (“A” in Japanese) for his hair and nose, and the other has a red slope (Akasaka) on her head.
The three mascots of Akasaka, Tokyo, are Akao-kun, Akarin-kun, and Akasakamen.
Psyduck (star of Pokemon Concierge) was in Shibuya Pokemon Center today.
Yep!
Bu-chan is a sumo wrestling pig who promotes Yabaton miso katsu, a local delicacy in Aichi Prefecture.
The surreal and mysterious Okazaemon, a mascot for Okazaki city, has 岡 (Oka) on his face and 崎 (Zaki) on his chest. He likes jazz, contemporary art, and black magic.
Ebiten-kun, a friendly fried shrimp wrestler, is a mascot for Tempura Wakataka, a tempura restaurant in Togoshi, Tokyo, that’s popular with wrestlers.
Direct-kun is a box of Ryukakusan Direct throat medicine wearing a top hat and bow tie.
Shibusawa-kun, the mascot of Kita Ward, Tokyo, is a 19th century industrialist.
Bin-kun is a bottle of yomeishu, a medicinal tonic (14% proof) for physical fatigue.
Raito-kun, a mascot Meiji Yasuda Insurance, was made for kids who aren't interested in insurance.
Iwashika-chan, a pink deer with pickled ginger antlers, is the mascot of Iwashita New Ginger Museum in Tochigi City.
Kamere-chan the turtle is the mascot of Atre Department Store in Kameido, Tokyo.
He is from France, originally. I guess he just morphed into a kidney shape.
Thank you! I’m enjoying it here.
Maybe an inspiration!
Children’s book character Barbapapa (and his car) in Tokyo
Pit-kun, a mild-mannered yellow fairy, is the mascot of Kokumin Kyosai Co-op (National Federation of Workers and Consumers).
The Tokyo 2020 Olympics mascots, Miraitowa and Someity, in Tokyo
Thank you!
That sounds delicious! I’d like to go there sometime.
Salmon-kun and Miyako-chan, a pair of salmon, are mascots for Miyako City’s fisheries.
Kerohira, the mascot of Hiraizumi, in Iwate, Japan, is based on an ancient caricature of a frog, which was excavated in the area.
I had a burger while I was there!
The Wanko Kyodai, lacquerware bowl siblings full of local delicacies from Iwate Prefecture, are in Tokyo today.
Mikyan (right), a hybrid of a puppy and a mandarin orange, is the mascot of Ehime Prefecture. He has a baby sidekick (Komikyan, middle) and an evil moldy version of himself, Dark Mikyan.
BLÅHAJ, IKEA's shark character, sitting around in the Shibuya IKEA.
Nashibou and Kaori, a pair of pears who are the official mascots of Shiroi City, are joined by Shiroi's unofficial mascot, Jinenger the mountain yam.
Mujinamon, a magical badger with a leaf on his head, and Igaman-chan, a mysterious fairy, are the mascots of Hanyu City.
Monnyan is a ninja cat who promotes monjayaki, is a pan-fried batter dish.
Capicle, a pink alien in a car, is the mascot for the Tokyo Used Car Sales Association.
Aya the flying squirrel appears in front of Tsuboyakiimo Momonga sweet potato shop, where she's the mascot.
Hokkaido TV's mascot is the spherical orange creature, On-chan.
Boona-chan the pig is the mascot of TBS television.
O-kun (green) and Baru-chan (pink) are the mascots for Oval Garden shopping mall in Shinagawa, Tokyo.
Izukyun is a sentient train car who's the mascot for the Izukyu train line.
I guess the game has a clothing line!
One-kun, a patchwork puppy with one button eye, is NieR Clothing's character.
The mascot of Inuyama City is Wanmaru-kun, a samurai Shiba Inu.
TureppoN, the mascot of Upopoy National Ainu Museum and Park in Hokkaido, is a bulb of turep, a plant from which the Ainu people extract starch to use in medicines and cooking.
Kuedon, a longtooth grouper fish, is a mascot for the beach resort town of Shirahama.
The mascot for JTB travel agency is JTon, a 3-year-old pig with intense emotions.
The giant toaster really helps!
Matsudo-san is the bouncy businessman mascot of Matsudo City. The kanji for Matsudo (松戸) is on his face.
Ichibantaro, the bear-like green alien mascot of Osaki, Tokyo, was walking around with Santa hats on his ears.
Yes, festive accessorizing!
Shin-Nyaka, the mascot of Shin-Nakamise shopping street in Asakusa, Tokyo, looks like a rabbit but is, in fact, a cat with its ears tied together like a bindle.
Not that I know of. I think he’s a kind of train creature.
Shinkichi-kun is the colour of the trains at the JR East Shinkansen General Vehicle Center where he’s the mascot.
Umemaru-kun is the plum-headed mascot for the town of Mutsuzawa in Chiba Prefecture.
Yeah, the disembodied one hanging on the wall.
Not really. A selection of animal butts!
Sugamon the duck, mascot of Sugamo, Tokyo, celebrates Christmas each year by dressing as Santa.
That’s Sugamon. I guess I’ll post him next!
Kumokkuru the cloud child is the mascot of the Shibuya Flower Project, who plant flowers in the city.
Samurai Tamabe, the mascot for Japan’s national baseball team, is a samurai who has a baseball mixed with a bear’s head on top of his own head.
Unari-kun, a mix of an eel and a plane, is the mascot of Narita City. He was in Asakusa, Tokyo, yesterday.
The pig itself is Bibuta. I guess Buden is the pig-based clothing line from Toyoten!
That’s Bibuta, who appears on Toyoten T-shirts. They seem to do a lot of large-size stuff—I have a few myself.
Oshinari-kun, a 9th Century poet with a tower on his head, meets a friend at a festive event in Asakusa, Tokyo.
Fukkachan, who has leeks for antlers, looking festive today in Asakusa, Tokyo
Thanks! I’ve seen a grape mascot from there, too.
Sometimes!

That’s Ofunaton, a hybrid of a camellia and a pig, from Ofunato City. I didn’t know that event was happening!
Some more mascots are appearing in Ueno Station today, too.
Momon-chan, whose head is a peach, is a mascot from Koshu City.
That looks entertaining!
Synapusyu is a character named after the synapse and appears in a TV show for babies.

Tsurupi, the tourism mascot for Tsuru City, is a flying squirrel with a water droplet nose, a plum blossom on his forehead, and a map of Tsuru on his belly. He's green like the city's official bird, the Japanese bush warbler.
Tsuge-san is the mascot of Kaizuka City and is based on a popular wooden comb manufactured there.
Kumamon wearing an Evangelion costume
Nomakey is the half-seagull, half-lighthouse mascot for the seaside town of Mihama, Japan, where young lovers attach padlocks to the local lighthouse for good luck.
Your memory is better than mine!
Digimon characters in Akihabara, Tokyo
Sato-chan and Satoko-chan, elephant siblings, are the mascots of Sato Pharmaceuticals.
Shinshu Riki, a sumo-sized stoat, is an agricultural mascot from Nagano, Japan.
I think it’s just a fuzzy mouth, but that is a mustache, I guess!

Ikubee, the bouncy fairy mascot for Aomori, Japan, is a big letter A for “Aomori” (which means “blue forest”—that’s why he’s blue) with an apple blossom hat. His name means “Let’s go” in the local dialect.
The Miyazaki Ken are three dancing dog siblings from Miyazaki Prefecture.
Picarya, the mascot for the town of Taketomi in Okinawa, is a rare Iriomote wildcat from the area.
Cupolan, from Kawaguchi City, is a robot based on the city's historic cupola furnace (used for making steel).
I ran into cable internet company JCOM’s bouncy mascot, ZAQ, and Itscom digital TV’s blue alien character, Comzo.
The same noodles that are on his head!
Wataru, a bridge with a car driving over it, is the mascot for Japan's Honshu-Shikoku Bridge.
I like the judo uniform!
Fukkura Tamako the rice fairy is the mascot of Tako, a town in Chiba, Japan.
Nanjii is the grandfatherly mascot of Nanjo City in Okinawa. A romantic soul, he officiates weddings and has an upside-down love heart on his face.
Mostly special occasions, but a few not-so-special ones, too.
All that tea
Irutea, an Eurasian skylark sumo wrestler who likes drinking tea, is the mascot of Iruma City.
Just hanging out, as far as I could see!
Namarin, a fashion-conscious catfish, is the mascot of Yoshikawa City.
Fujimaru-kun, a spherical superhero who can create rainbow-coloured dreams, is the mascot for Fuji Shoji, who make pachinko machines.
Japan’s human rights mascots are Jin-KEN-Mamoru-kun and Jin-KEN-Ayumi-chan.
Bocchi-kun is a mascot from Yachimata City where peanuts are farmed. “Bocchi” are bails of harvested peanuts left out to dry in the fields in autumn.
Vegasus-kun, a psychedelic unicorn, is the mascot of Vegas Vegas Pachinko Parlor in Shinjuku, Tokyo.
Tamagotchi character Mametchi in Shibuya today
Kenchi-kun, an orange house with hands, is a character created by the Tokyo Association of Architects.
Musashi Ranmaru, a naughty boy in a butterfly helmet, is the mascot for the scenic town of Arashiyama in Saitama Japan.
Buruburu-kun the giant blueberry is the mascot of Wakasa Seikatsu supplements.
Toyotama, a spherical chicken with cars for feet, is the mascot for Toyota Motors in Saitama, Japan.
Sphia, a kitten who wants to be a sphinx, is the mascot for Himawarikan, who sell nursing care equipment.
It’s one of these, promoting his town: en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Happi
Gyoda Mamekichi, a sentient green soybean, is the mascot for Gyoda City.
Umemaru-kun, the plum-headed mascot for the town of Mutsuzawa in Chiba Prefecture, was wearing a Santa hat at the mascot festival.
Sadandy, a bird fairy with a lighthouse atop its head, is from Sadamisaki, Japan's longest and narrowest peninsula.
Micchan the honey bee helps make stuffed animals at GS Craft toy speciality store in Kyoto.
Awabuta, a pig covered in bubbles, is the mascot of Eaglestar Chemicals.
Risonya the cat is the mascot for Resona Bank.
That’s Usagohan, the nutrition mascot for Nakano. It’s half-rabbit, half-rice bowl.
Qnosuke, a weasel with a straw hat, is a mascot from Kasukabe City.
Alas, I can’t tell from that photo.
The mascots of Oyama City are Fuunya, an orange-brown tabby, and his younger brother Mumunya, a grey tabby who clings to Funya’s head.
Momiji also has a rifle!
Jin-kun the sheep and Momiji-chan the deer, selling their merch
They’re often just cosplaying other mascots, which can get confusing!
Some of them have a different outfit whenever I see them, Darth!
This one is a solo operator. (But I have seen unrelated kappa mascots of various other colours!)
Kappa Green, a stylish water imp, is the mascot for Aizuwakamatsu City.
That’s an accidental olive!
There are a couple more legs down there somewhere. I’m not sure if walking on two legs makes a cow more of less laid back, Darth!
Konsen-kun, a laid-back green and white cow, is the mascot for Konsen 72 milk.
Mascots at the World Character Summit in Hanyu City
Yes, he was there too, Darth!
I hope to see more mascot luggage!
Kitekero-kun, mascot of Yamagata Prefecture, is shaped like the outline of Yamagata, and carries local produce around in a suitcase.

That’s Anpanman.
en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anpanman
Pi-chan and Na-chan, a pair of peanuts, are mascots for Yachimata City.
And thank you!
Kikunon, a green tea fairy with a teacup on his head, is the mascot of Kikugawa City. He was in Hanyu City this week.
Momo, a girl dressed as a pink owl, is a mascot from Hong Kong. (She came to the World Character summit in Hanyu City yesterday.)
I’ve seen some for a quite a few places.
Honuppi the sea turtle promotes Hawaii in Japan.
Sokanyan, the cat from Soka City, meets Fukkachan, the mascot of Fukaya City (a mysterious creature with leeks for antlers).
Jingiskan No Jin-kun, a lamb from Sapporo City, at the World Character Summit in Hanyu City today
Akita dog mascots came to Shibuya today to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of famous local dog Hachiko.
Akabou-kun is the mascot of the National Federation of Light Vehicle Transport Cooperatives. (He's a red and blue cap, which drivers used to wear.)
Shichimaru, a dog whose head is a warehouse, is the mascot for Japan's national pawnshop association.
Hato-san and Hato-chan, a pair of pigeons, are the mascots for the property rental site, Hatosan.
I’m not sure where you’d get one. They don’t have them on his site.
Shihotan, a white rabbit with a red bow tie and a legal book, is the mascot for the Tokyo Judicial Scriveners’ Association.
He might have trouble getting through the door
Yes, giant dog heads must be protected at all costs, Darth!
DoKen-chan is the mascot for the Shibuya branch of the Tokyo construction workers’ union.
Several Akita dogs (including Hachi-kun, from Akita Prefecture) at the Shibuya hometown festival.
Myna-chan, a bunny with 1s for eyes, is the mascot for Japan's "My Number" system (a number everyone gets for social security, tax, etc.)
Shibuya Hachi (a tourism mascot based on Shibuya’s famous faithful Akita dog, Hachiko) was at the Shibuya Hometown Festival last week.
The Greek god Zeus is now working as the mascot for Macy pachinko parlors in Japan.
Niracco, a bright, energetic, and interesting blue sea otter, is the new mascot of Niraku pachinko parlors.
I was wondering about that, but I can’t think of anything!
Gin-chan, a cheerful red bird, is the mascot of NewGin Pachinko Parlors.
Eiriyan is the green alien mascot of Sammy's Slot Machines and Pachinko.
Quite a big chunk!
I saw the Odakyu railway line’s new blue bunny mascot, Mokoron today.
Chicky the penguin is a mascot for the Tokyo Sports Culture Foundation.
Yes, that’s right! The town is known for mining, so they added the helmet.
I think it’s meant to be a cute version of this thing, Darth:
Ja-Bow, the mascot of Omuta City, is a snake monster, designed by the creator of Yokai Watch.
I stopped by The Kawaii Monster Cafe pop-up in Harajuku, and saw Choppy the monster.
Todorocky is a musclebound sea lion boxer from Todoroki, Tokyo.
Koakkuma and Akkuma, horned space bear twins from Hokkaido, wearing Halloween costumes
Udon Nou, a mascot from Kagawa Prefecture who has noodles for brains, is the winner of this year’s Yuruchara Grand Prix (mascot popularity poll).
Melon Kuma, a terrifying hybrid of a melon and a bear, is the mascot of Yubari City (where melons are grown and bears roam).
Costumes within costumes!
I’ve seen them perform a few times. They rock!
Kakitan, a bear-shaped god who likes persimmons, is an agricultural mascot for Hashimoto City. Here’s Kakitan in a Halloween costume:
Mikyan, a mix of a dog and a mandarin orange, in a Halloween witch costume
Udolla, a monster mutated from a locally grown vegetable, the udo, is an unofficial mascot for Tachikawa, Tokyo. He was wearing a Halloween costume today.
Iga Gurio, a young chestnut-headed ninja rodent with a large belly cultivated by enjoying local delicacies, is the mascot for lga City, Japan. Here he is in a Halloween costume.
Zombear is a zombie bear mascot from Otaru, in Hokkaido, who swings his intestines around.
Minowan, a dog with an upside-down mountain neckerchief, is the mascot of Minobu, a town in scenic Yamanashi Prefecture.
It’s looks like this, Darth. You can’t really tell it’s the Milky Way.
Hoshino Aman, a space monster who has a star on its head and the Milky Way for a tail, is the mascot of Katano City, where there is a star festival.
Not a melon fan, Darth?
Melo and Cosumin are a pair of melon-bodied siblings from Miyadae, in Kawasaki City.
Pompoko-chan, the mascot for Shigaraki, a town in Koka City, is a baby tanuki (raccoon dog) girl who's always smiling.
Iwakun, the mascot of Iwakura City, is a kid dressed as a koinobori (a traditional carp-shaped windsock).
Shinagawan is the mascot dog for cable TV in Shinagawa, Tokyo.
Shinart is a beret-wearing bird who promotes art activities in Shinagawa, Tokyo.
That’s always fun to see!
Lots, on other platforms. I’ll post some here soon!
She’s the mascot for Kusatsu onsen resort in Gunma, and this guy is from Kusatsu City in Shiga Prefecture. A bit confusing!
Tabimaru, a portly boy in a hat, is the mascot of Kusatsu City. He likes making friends, travelling, and telling people about Kusatsu.
The mascot of Akita Prefecture, Ndatchi, is a cute version of Akita's legendary folkloric monster, the Namahage.
Amazing!
Inappy, the mascot of Inazawa city, is yellow like autumnal ginkgo leaves, has ashitaba leaves for hair, and wears the skimpy traditional costume of the city's annual "nude festival".
Zelvy-kun, the mascot of FC Machida Zelvia, is a blue-headed kingfisher.
Nana-chan, a cat with a fish in its front pocket, is the mascot of Obama City, Japan.

Keio Bus mascots Pinpon and Panpon, in
Shinjuku Bus Terminal
Abenon, a fashionable fairy with a peach flower on its head, is the mascot of Abeno Ward, Osaka City.
Kurawanko, a laid-back dog, and Hiranyanko, a capricious cat, are the mascots of Hirakata City, and both wear loincloths.
Today in Tokyo I ran into Manekineko Duck, who is Aflac’s duck mascot in a lucky cat costume.
Chicchai Ossan, a balding middle-aged man with a beer belly, is the popular unofficial mascot of Amagasaki City.
Well, there’s even another mascot for the town itself: Shirapen, a penguin whose face is an aerial view of the beach.
Captain Shirahama is the mascot for a glass-bottom boat tour in the coastal town of Shirahama.
He’s very dapper indeed, Darth!
Taiga-san, a dapper tiger from Toranomon, Tokyo, is the mascot for the anime channel AT-X.
Nyaganohara, a cat with a mountain hat and a loincloth from the local hot spring festival, is the mascot for the town of Naganohara in Gunma, Japan.
Nuts-kun, a squirrel with tree hair, is a mascot from the town of Satosho in Okayama, Japan.
Fujipyon, a pink bunny whose head is shaped like Mt. Fuji, is a mascot from Fujikawaguchiko, a town in Yamanashi, Japan.
Susie, an unidentified creature, is the mascot for the Tokyo Sports Benefits Corporation.
Rook, of basketball team Alvark Tokyo, is one of the more lethargic sports mascots.
Fucat, a cat with a target on its face, is a mascot for fukiya (competitive blow darts).
It’s a box of soy milk
Chaotic mascots Chiitan and Tonyu-kun in Tokyo National Stadium today
Chickens Heartorin and Akarin are mascots for the supermarket chain Torisen.
Kasayan, the smiling mascot for the town of Kasagi in Kyoto, rides a boat in Hikone. He is a Nekomata (cat yōkai) who guides tourists and has two tails.
Tsuchiura City’s mascot is Tsuchimaru, who has lotus root ears and waddles like a toddler.
Fukuiine-kun is a hand with a raised thumb who promotes Fukui Prefecture.
Yeah. You won’t be able to get your hands the whole way round, though!
It seemed to love all the mascots, Darth!
Mascots Yuzugappa and Akkuma meet a shiba inu.
Pearanne is a French exchange student pear fairy staying in Funabashi City.
Shirakaba-chan is a white birch tree from the town of Sakuho in Nagano, Japan
Hyakuman-san, a floral-patterned traditional doll with a mustache, is the mascot of Japan’s Ishikawa Prefecture.
Mitsudon the apple fairy is the mascot of Iizuna, a town in Nagano, Japan. His face is the star shape you find in the center of Fuji apples.
Chiitan still posts a few times a day on Twitter, Instagram, Threads, and YouTube.
I hear it’s expensive!
They’re usually selling lots of merch!
There are thousands, and they range from big companies with famous designers and trained performers to small villages with local citizens designing and performing them.
Mikke-chan is a ballet-dancing calico cat from Hirakata City.
Coroton the spherical pig is the mascot of Maebashi City.
I ran into Kumamon yesterday.
I went to the 30th birthday party of Gunma Prefecture's pony mascot, Gunma-chan.
Picarya, the mascot for the town of Taketomi in Okinawa, is a rare Iriomote wildcat from the area. The pattern on his belly represents the islands of Taketomi.
Yachinyan, a feline version of a legendary local princess, appears in the window of a shop in Yonbancho Square (where she's the mascot) in Hikone City.
I haven’t seen one yet!
Levmaru the lion is the tourism mascot for the Czech Republic in Japan.
Consarun, an apprentice insurance consultant lemur, is the mascot for Aeon Insurance.
Sanudon the udon noodle fairy, whose eyebrows are based on a mountain, promotes Sanuki udon from Kagawa, Japan.
That’s great! -25°C sounds like the best temperature for it.
That’s cool! How was the experience?
Quite a few!
The Fuwappi twins, who wear Mt. Fuji onesies, are the mascots of Fujimi City (near the mountain).
That’s its name here!
Hinojaga-kun, a potato-headed lad, is the mascot for the village of Hinohara, in Tokyo.
Hamurin, mascot of Hamura City, leads a parade of mascots from Tokyo’s Nishitama area.

Iruma-chan, a green bird with flowers in her hair and wearing a tea bowl, is the mascot for AEON Style Mall in Iruma City, Saitama.
Sudachi-kun is one of the Japan's oldest regional mascots. The citrus fruit-headed superhero mascot of Tokushima Prefecture has been around for 30 years.
